subject: Bundling the Wild Cards
event: Haven't tried Wild Cards yet? Well, here's your chance. Tor Books is doing a special ebook bundle of the first five volumes of Wild Cards. (Including the new editions of volumes one and four, with five additional stories). The whole bundle is available for only $39.99, starting today, from https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01N4FQ1X1 or http://us.macmillan.com/books/9780765397188 Here's your chance to find out who Gregg Hartmann is, meet Dr. Tachyon and the Four Aces, ride with Jetboy on his last flight, go into action with the Great and Powerful Turtle, hang with Fortunato and hunt with Yeoman. Can't beat that. Once you've read the first five books, of course, you'll be reaching for volume six, ACE IN THE HOLE. We've got good news on that front as well. Tor will be releasing the long-awaited reissue on February 28, in trade paperback. With another stunning cover from Michael Komarck. Fly high, aces!

comments.article:
Would like to ask a question and it has nothing to do with game of thrones :)
Wild cards looks awesome, I'm tempted to read them.
Tho I like more medieval books. (Yours being my favourite)

After game of thrones, do you ever think you would do a Medieval fantasy/ Or Medieval story again.
Or even better question would you like to do another series based on this genre?
comments.subject: Books

comments.article:
I will likely write more stories set in the world of Westeros after ICE & FIRE. Dunk and Egg, for starts.

Will I ever attempt another seven-book megaseries set in an entirely different fantasy world? Unlikely.

I have other stories I want to tell too. SF as well as fantasy. More Wild Cards, more Thousand Worlds.

comments.article:
I am still on book four and I lost this week dispute between Trump and fictional characters, to which, I would cast my vote for Hartmann for reasons too long to explain, but I'll try to make it short. He is a career politician that although DOES have split personality disorder or schizophrenia or whatever you would like to call the reasons for his murderous urges, he does have best intention for others (Jokers included), sure, one might say it's a political move to win votes, but most (or all) politicians will do that along their career. The problem would be if Hartmann ended up using his powers to keep himself in power indefinitely, which I don't think he would (as I said, I only finished Aces Abroad, so I don't know if later it would show with the hints of a dictator).
Anyway, Wild Cards has been my favorite super-hero universe since I read about it GURPS Supers back in the 90s (and in Brazil that was my only source of the whole universe until imported books became more common and two years ago they started translating them).
Keep reading. Just wait for it.

Hello!
I don't think you have any power on that but I started reading Wild Cards in the French edition by "J'ai lu", and to my surprise the ink diden't stick to the pages and I have now a Wild Card example full of my fingerprints and less words in it.
Note that I'm not complaining, I love having special books, and altough I would get one clean and dry for free if I'd give back mine, there's no way I'd get rid of it.
That book will ever stay alongside my Glen Cook's Black Company where it took me several years and an another example to find out that the couple pages I thought was missing was in fact TWO CHAPTERS...
Same editor...
In my opinion a bad edition is better than none but in this case they went for such a cheap ink (I guess) that it may very well impact negatively on Wild Cards, for 10 euros it would not be an issue but for 20 euros they are bad cooks destroying a good recipe.
But again, I understand that you may not have any power in that matter.

Anyway, due to translation times, I must thank you again, the wait for ASOIAF to get translated got me to read in English (wich I did but it was a pain) and, being ahead of the Wild Cards one, I bought an english version knowing that I'll be able to enjoy it.
You're currently the only writers I care enough to read in english ( others I can find in French and I'm lazy) but I'm planning to read Shakespeare one day and if I do it will all be thanks to you, so there's that.

Salut et merci pour le poisson!

comments.article:
I know how much you love off topic posts but I read that post about you having more SF stories to tell and I can't help it.

Man, I'd love to read more science fiction from you before you retire. I know this Ice and Fire thing is kind of big and unfinished (were you aware of that?) but you have written some truly amazing sci fi in your day. I feel like you've gotten better with age. More patient, perhaps, but whatever the reason, I'd love to see a modern sci fi story from you.

This makes me want to re-read Nightflyers but I don't think I still have my copy of that short story collection you released ages ago. I think A Song for Lya was in there, too. Nightflyers was the centerpiece for me, though. That Ridley Scott feel to it was just awesome. I remember being legitimately scared shitless for the crew. The atmosphere you built there was terrific. The ending is legendary.

It'd be a damn shame if you don't get at least one more short story out of your abilities in that genre. I know 90% of your fans would FREAK out (and I mean that in a true sense) if you did this, but I wouldn't mind if you pulled a Stephen King and wrote something else for awhile after Winds. It was never as big as your series, but it was never all Dark Tower, all the time for him. Same with Glen Cook, it wasn't The Black Company constantly. It kind of sucks that's the hand you've been dealt. I'd love to see you explore some of the ideas you're bound to have going on. Some of them are most likely great...

Well, whatever... just rambling. Sorry about that. Love that cover. I just got my first Kindle for Christmas so I'll make sure to pick this up. Have a good 2017, George.

PS: Sorry about football but being a Cleveland fan, fuck football.
comments.subject: Somewhat off topic
